history.content: Piazza is a Q&A platform designed to get you great answers from classmates and instructors fast. We've put together this list of tips you might find handy as you get started: 1. Ask questions! The best way to get answers is to ask questions! Ask questions on Piazza rather than emailing your teaching staff so everyone can benefit from the response (and so you can get answers from classmates who are up as late as you are). 2. Edit questions and answers wiki-style. Think of Piazza as a Q&A wiki for your class. Every question has just a single students' answer that students can edit collectively (and a single instructors’ answer for instructors). 3. Add a followup to comment or ask further questions. To comment on or ask further questions about a post, start a followup discussion. Mark it resolved when the issue has been addressed, and add any relevant information back into the Q&A above. 4. Go anonymous. Shy? No problem. You can always opt to post or edit anonymously. 5. Tag your posts. It's far more convenient to find all posts about your Homework 3 or Midterm 1 when the posts are tagged. Type a “#” before a key word to tag. Click a blue tag in a post or the question feed to filter for all posts that share that tag. 6. Format code and equations. Adding a code snippet? Click the pre or tt button in the question editor to add pre-formatted or inline teletype text. Mathematical equation? Click the Fx button to access the LaTeX editor to build a nicely formatted equation. 7. View and download class details and resources. Click the Course Page button in your top bar to access the class syllabus, staff contact information, office hours details, and course resources—all in one place! Contact the Piazza Team anytime with questions or comments at team@piazza.com. We love feedback!

history.content: The set (1,2) contains all reals x such that 1 &lt; x &lt; 2. In other words, it contains all of the points in the interval [1,2] but *not* the end points.

history.content: The empty set is a subset of every set.
The empty set is in every set.
The empty set is in every set. {5} has the element 5 and nothing, but we don't have to show it like {5, }

The statement $$X \subseteq Y$$ is true if:
every element $$x \in X$$ is also in $$Y$$.  

For every element of $$\emptyset$$, let's check that the element is also in $$\{5\}$$.  There are no elements in $$\emptyset$$, so we're done!  $$\emptyset \subseteq \{5\}$$ is true.

history.subject: Problem 1 Part II

history.content:
(1,2) = set of reals *strictly* between 1 and 2.  So this set includes 1.5, 1.7, 1.00001, but not 1 and 2.  

So (1,2) is not a subset of {1,2}, since 1.5 is in the set (1,2) but not in the set {1,2}.

The question asks: Suppose balls come in 11 colors and that you are to pick out 3 balls. How many different color combinations are possible?

Wouldn't the answer follow the format n!/(k!(n-k!))? The answer I'm putting in isn't working for me. Thanks! 
#homework
history.subject: Question 5: Part 3

history.content:
(n choose k) is not the right answer. It is the answer to the question "you have n balls, k of them are red, (n-k) of them are white, how many color patterns are possible. Note that in this case the number of colors is 2. Here you need to pick  3 balls from 11 color choices (each containing at least 3 balls) and the order does not matter. Suppose the colors are numbered 1 - 11. Then you possibilities are {1,1,1},{1,1,2},{1,2,2},....

Calculating this is not trivial. Read the guided solution of "choosing candy".

That input would be accepted but the answer itself is incorrect assuming you typed it correctly. If you are in doubt about whether the format is acceptable you can always just try to simplify it to a number.

children.subject: 11! is not correct. See my response above.
the guided solution is pretty confusing to me, I have a hard time following the bars and stars part
Instead of bars and stars, try thinking of it as colors and the number of balls of that color

I can understand that the stars and bars concept may be somewhat difficult to grasp. 

I can try to explain it in a way that makes more sense to me, and hopefully it will make it more clear but at least I hope it doesn't confuse you further.

The way I think of using stars and bars is that we are reducing the problem of finding the number of color combinations we can make with c colors and b balls into the problem of finding the number of ways to arrange a string of stars and bars. We can do this because for every color combination, there is exactly one corresponding arrangement of stars and bars. Why is this the case? 

Well, you can try to imagine that we have an arrangement of c boxes each with at least b balls, and a robot named Rob. Rob reads input from a tape as stars and bars, and he reads one character at a time. Rob starts at the leftmost box, and whenever he reads a star, he takes out a ball from the box he is currently at, and whenever he reads a bar, he moves to the next box(to the right).

Now, if we want b balls, then clearly we want his tape to have b stars. Also, since we have c colors but start from the first one already, we would need c-1 bars so that it's possible for Rob to take out a ball from any of the c boxes of different colored balls. Lastly, we can see that for every color combination we can easily construct the string of stars and bars that would have Rob pick out the right number of times from each box. First, we sort the color combination in the same order as the boxes are ordered(we can do this since order doesn't matter with combinations). Then, we append to the initially empty string the number of bars we need to move to the box we want to get a ball from, append the number of stars depending on how many we want, and repeat until we have chosen all the balls. After the last star the remaining bars don't do anything since Rob would just move to the next box and not grab anything. So, by construction we can see that finding the number of ways to arrange stars and bars with b stars and c-1 bars solves the number of color combinations we can make with b balls and c colors. 

If it's still not clear perhaps I can provide an example. Let's say we have 3 colors: red,white, black, and we want to get 3 balls. We can let our imaginary row of boxes balls be arranged in that same order: (red, white, black).

One possible color combination is RWB. How do we get the corresponding stars and bars? We can have * | * | *  which would make us pick out a red, move to white, pick out a white, move to black, and pick out a black.
Another possible color combination is RRR. To get this , we would have * * * | | which would make us pick out 3 reds, then move to white and black(not picking any of those).
And yet another one is WWB. To get this, we need | * * | * which would make us move to white, pick 2, then move to black, and pick the final one. 

One final note is that for the color combinations, order is irrelevant, so WWB is the same as WBW or BWW. The only thing we need to know is that there are 2 whites and 1 black, and the order in which we get them is irrelevant. 

If I just made things even more complicated, sorry and forget everything I said.

The way I see this question is that there are 3 different balls and 11 different colors (and order does not matter), so there are 3 positions to pick 11 different colors. So wouldn't the answer be 11 * 11 * 11, because there are always 11 choices of colors for each ball. I have a variation of this question in terms of number of colors and balls, but I'm guessing that I am missing a point somewhere because this result is incorrect...

Jeffrey, the reason it's incorrect is because it is asking for combinations, so order doesn't count. If the question were asking for permutations of colored balls, then your answer would be correct.

In short, 11^3 is overcounting because you count ABB differently BAB whereas as far as combinations are concerned they are equivalent.

Hmm I seem to be having trouble with my Q5's part 3 too. The question I had involved 8 colors and choosing 2 balls, but when I input 28, it said that it was incorrect. Did I misinterpret the problem if that was not the correct answer?

You are correct that (8 choose 2) = 28. Your mistake is that there are 8 *colors* not 8 *balls* each with a different color. You should suppose that there are many balls from each color (in this case, 2 from each color would be enough). Therefor, in addition to one ball from each color, you have the 8 patterns consisting of two balls of the same color, (red,red), (yellow,yellow) etc.

So the correct answer, in this case, is (8 choose 2)+8 = 36.

However, things get much more interesting and complex when you replace the 2 with 3 or 4 or 5..

Therefor I suggest you read the choosing candy problem and solution carefully, so you would know how to apply it to this case.

history.content:
Matt went over the stars and bars concept during discussion today. Basically you consider the amount you can choose from as "bins" and the amount of items you want to pick out as the "stars". In your example, the bars should look something like this:
| | | | | | | | | |
The spaces between the bars will serve as the bins and the items will fall in between, ie:
*| | |* | | | |* | | |
From there, you add the amount of stars and bars you have placed and that would be your sequence size. Don't count the empty spaces in between the bars either. Finally, you follow the formula that you mentioned and you should get your answer.

Matt went over the stars and bars concept during discussion today. Basically you consider the amount you can choose from as "bins" and the amount of items you want to pick out as the "stars". In your example, the bars should look something like this:
|  |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |
The spaces between the bars will serve as the bins and the items will fall in between, ie:
*|  |  |* |  |  |  |* |  |  |
From there, you add the amount of stars and bars you have placed and that would be your sequence size. Don't count the empty spaces in between the bars either. Finally, you follow the formula that you mentioned and you should get your answer.

history.content: Problem 5 - The number of bars represents the total number of candies. Essentially, (Number of Candies of Type 1) | (Number of Candies of Type 2) | (Number of Candies of Type 3) | (Number of Candies of Type 4) | (Number of Candies of Type 5). Instead of writing a number, we just place that many stars. Problem 8(b) - What is it that you don't understand about the question?

For your word question, you have an unknown number of words that is larger than the different possible words allowed, which means that there are some repeated words. You're asked to find the size of the set such that a given word is repeated at least 9 times. on a side note, i'm not sure such a question is fair if it requires the knowledge of the pidgeon-hole principle, and if such a concept was not yet taught (or reviewed) in class. For problem 5, it might help if you think of it this way. You have one big box divided up into 5 sections, representing the different types of candies. To properly divide up the box, you want one less divider than the number of spaces you need, like this: __ | __ | __ | __ | __ (um, pretend there's a box) These "dividers" will be your bars. So in the example, 5 types - 1 = 4 bars You can put your candies into any section of the box, but there are always 3. You can do * * | __ | * | __ | __ or __| __ |__ | * * * | __ or __ | * | * | * | __ or whatever, but there are always 4 dividers/bars and 3 candies/stars. So, for every combination of stars and bars for this example, there are 7 total spaces to fill. And of those 7 spaces, you choose 3 places to put the stars and fill the rest in with bars. (Hopefully that didn't make it worse...)

children.subject:
For those not familiar with the pigeon hole principle (by the way, i should have said the generalized version of the pigeon hole principle)

suppose you are tasked to fit some pigeons into a given number of holes
if the number of pidgeon exceeds the numbe of holes, then there will be at least 1 hole with more than one pidgeon, thus the name

Using math notation, let X be a set of objects, and Y be another set of objects, and you have a function that links the two sets
if the size of X is greater than the size of Y, then some elements in X will point to the same element in Y

If the inequality |X| &gt; |Y| (repeated_Objects - 1) is true, than there is at least a subset of X such that it contains repeated_Objects number of elements. (source: David Hunter: Essentials of Discrete Mathematics, 2nd edition)

history.content:
any one can tell me what is the difference between permutation and combination?
Thanks!! 
#question
history.subject: permutation and combination

history.content:
So the difference is that for permutations, the order matters, while for combinations they don't. I think it's easier to explain with an example. 

So, let's say we have 5 people in a contest. If we want to find the number of ways people can place 1st, 2nd, or 3rd, then we would need to find permutations. That is, the matter in which the people are placed is relevant. Then, Alice, Bob, and Charles is a valid permutation and Bob, Alice, and Charles, is another valid permutation, and they are not equivalent because the first corresponds to Alice being first, Bob 2nd, and so forth while the other one corresponds to Bob being first and so on. 

However, if we are only looking for the number of combinations in which 3 people place, and we don't care about the order in which they place, then the order is irrelevant. That is, Alice, Bob, and Charles being placed is equivalent to Bob, Charles, and Alice.

You can also think of it as the number of ways we can make sets of 3 people as opposed to tuples of 3 people, corresponding to combinations and permutations respectively. 

In short, the order is significant in permutations while for combinations it is not. For a permutation, (a, b, c) is not the same as (b, a, c) while for combinations they are the same.

children.subject:
Well, first let's try to think about what the difference is between having cards be discrete or identical. So if we put identical cards into envelopes, it doesn't matter what order we put them because we can't tell them apart. In that scenario, the only thing we can tell after putting all cards into envelopes is how many cards are in each envelope.

But, for part 1 they are not identical but discrete, so let's just say they are numbered. After putting all the numbered cards into envelopes, we can tell which card was put in which envelope, we can tell more than just how many cards were in each envelope. More specifically, we can tell exactly which card is in which envelope. 

In the discrete case then, it's equivalent to having $$c$$ people each pick some number between 1 and $$e$$ where $$c$$ is how many cards we have and $$e$$ is how many envelopes. In that case, we know that the first person has $$e$$ numbers he or she could pick, as does the second, and so on.

Now observe that these conditions are equivalent to the problem of picking 25 pieces of candy when 4 flavors are available. To which the
solution, as we already found is (25+3)! / (25! 3!)

children.subject:
Hello. I'm not really sure what you are confused about, so I'll just try to give an explanation and hopefully after reading it you'll understand it better or at least be able to identify what part confuses you.

I'm going to replace x1 x2 and x3 with a, b, and c just so it's easier to type.

First, we need to state that no matter what a, b, and c are, $$(30 - c) + (c - b) + (b - a) + (a - 5)$$ will always be the same. This should be obvious because if you expand it, it will end up being $$30 - 5 = 25$$.

Now that we've established that, we use this to change this problem into something that's more familiar to us and perhaps easier to solve. So, we have variables: a, b, and c, and instead of reasoning about the variables themselves, we instead want to reason about the differences $$(30 - c)$$, $$(c - b)$$, $$(b - a)$$, and $$(a - 5)$$. Why can we do this? Well, there is a one to one correspondence between these differences and the values of the variables a, b, and c. 

For example, you can see that in the case $$a = b = c = 5$$, we must have $$(a - 5 = 0)$$, $$(b - a = 0)$$, $$(c - b = 0)$$, and $$(30 - c = 25)$$. Try more examples to convince yourself that this works. Formally, we know that for any a, $$a - 5$$ will be unique to that a. Then, for any b given some a, $$b - a$$ is also a one to one function, and the same for c. 

Now, we use these findings to reduce the problem to something we already know how to solve. We can consider the differences to each be "buckets" of which there are 4. Then,we can consider the actual value of the difference to be the number of "balls" inside of it. So in the case that $$a = 8$$, the "bucket" $$a - 5$$ would have 3 "balls".

This is just a stars and bars problem, which we know how to solve! With that we get $$\frac{ (25 + 4 - 1)! } { (4 - 1)!25! }$$

history.subject: Question 1 (HW 3) # of combinations of pair
Question 1 (HW 3) # of combinations of pair

history.content:
Part 1 is asking only about the ranks, not the suites, so you can treat all those pairs with same rank but different suites as identical.
Your concern about the suites is actually asked in part 2. Multiplying the answers in both parts will give you the total number of combinations for a pair, counting variations in both ranks and suites, that is the 13*6 you brought out in the question.
The reason we break this calculation into 2 steps is to let you be aware of the independence of ranks and suites in many of these poker hand questions. We hope this would make it easier for you to understand the logics behind getting the final answer.

Problem 1, straight

history.content:
In fact I think you are under counting, because the order does matter. The order matters because the cards are distinct. 

Your intuition is correct in that the remainder four cards can not be the same as the first card. However, the problem with your solution is that you make it so that all of the remaining cards can not be the same as the first card, while that is not necessarily true. All we need is that at least one of them is not the same. Hence, what you are counting is things like (S, D, D, D, D) but not something like (S, D, S, D, D) since you only give 3 options for the remaining three cards.

children.subject:

However, perhaps another way to think about it is to think about the number of ways things can go wrong. What are the permutations that we don't want? 

Try to do them both ways as it will help boost your understanding for the final, since you never know which method you will need.

Okay so I tried out splitting it into cases, and it turns out it's rather nontrivial. Or at least, while not particularly conceptually difficult, there are so many cases that for the purposes of solving this problem, I don't recommend you try to do it this way by hand. However, I would still recommend you think about it so that should that method prove to be better for some other problem you would know how to do it.

history.content:
A poker hand consisting of 7 cards is dealt from a standard deck of 52 cards. Find the probability that the hand contains exactly 2 cards of the same suit. You just need to ensure there is one set of such 2 cards. For the other suits in the hand, it is allowed to have any number of cards in those suits.

From my understanding,the possibility of choosing 2 cards are the same suit is ( 13! ) / ( 2! * 11! ) = 78, and we have 4 suits, which is 13!/(2!11!) * 4 = 312 . and there are 39 cards left, to choose 5 of them, the possibility is ( 39! ) / ( 5! * 34!) = 575757 , but this number contains the possibility of 4 cards are the same suit, and 3 cards are the same suit, which are the cases we don't want.
For 4 cards are the same suit from 39 cards with 3 suits:
13! / (4! * 9!) = 715, 715 * 3 = 2145
For 3 cards are the same suit from 39 cards with 3 suits:
13! /(3! * 10!) = 286, 286 * 3 = 858

overall, 575757 - 2145 - 858 = 572754 this the possibility to choose 5 cards from 39 cards.
and we have 312 * 572754 which is a number greater the possibility to choose 7 cards from 52 cards.

I think I must be understanding something wrong.

ps: and from 5 cards the are same suit:
13! / (5! * 8!) = 1287 * 3 =3861, 572754 - 3861= 568893

312 * 568893 = 1211174209 witch still greater.

Hi, I think you are confused by the question's wording and so over thinking it a little bit.

When it says, "Find the probability that the hand contains exactly 2 cards of the same suit. You just need to ensure there is one set of such 2 cards. For the other suits in the hand, it is allowed to have any number of cards in those suits", it's saying that you just need to ensure there is some suit that has exactly 2 cards. For the other cards, it's totally fine if there are 5 of the same suit or things like that, so long as it's not the same suit as the suit of the first 2 cards.

history.content: I was asked in and after class to explain why it is that a uniform distribution over the segment [0,1] (called a uniform density distribution) assigns zero probability to any single point $$x \in [0,1]$$. Here is a proof by contradition: Lets assume that $$\forall x \in [0,1]; p(x)=\epsilon \mbox{ where } \epsilon>0$$, or, in words, every point has the same probability $$\epsilon$$ such that $$\epsilon > 0$$. (all the points have to have the same probability, as this is a uniform distribution. Now consider the set $$A$$ the consists of the infinite sequence of points $$1,1/2,1/3,1/4,\cdots$$ clearly $$A \subseteq [0,1]$$ and therefor $$P(A)\leq P([0,1])=1$$, but on the other hand, $$P(A)=\sum_{i=1}^\infty P\left(\frac{1}{i} \right) = \infty \epsilon = \infty$$ and we reach a contradiction. #density
history.subject: Uniform distribution over [0,1] means any single point has probability zero

history.content:
You're not missing anything.  Typing in a ratio of large factorials (eg 400!/396!) breaks the system, so I would instead write out the product (eg 400*399*398*397).  

An event set is just some set of outcomes.  So when someone says "size of the event set corresponding to this event", you should think "how many outcomes correspond to this event".  So you should think "how many outcomes are there where the birthdays are different".  

"These marbles picked have all different colors" and "At least two marbles picked have the same color" are complimentary events (one event happening implies the other is false).  So P("All these marbles have different colors") = 1 - P("At least two marbles have the same color")

history.content:
Allow me to help! I'm assuming that you're asking about the question
  • What is the size of the event set | =
Well, as outlined in the problem, we represent the collection of i people's birthdays as a tuple of four numbers 1 - 365, which each number representing a particular day in the year and i representing the total number of people. For this problem, the size of the tuple is irrelevant, so I decided to go with i = 4. This means that {1,2,3,4} would be the set where Person 1 has a birthday on January 1st, Person 2 has a birthday on January 2nd, Person 3 has a birthday on January 3rd, and so on and so forth. Thus, the event set of a situation where Person 1 has a birthday on January 1st, Person 2 has a birthday on January 2nd, Person 3 has a birthday on January 3rd and Person 4 has a birthday on January 4th is only one. This is because not only are the birthdays specified, but also the order of the set is specified. {4, 3, 2, 1} would not be in the event set because the order is wrong - Person 1 has a birthday on January 4th, Person 2 has a birthday on January 3rd, Person 3 has a birthday on January 2nd and Person 4 has a birthday on January 4th - this violates the conditions specified by the event for which we're analyzing. So the problem asks you about the size of the event set where every person has a birthday of January 1 - which should be clear after reading that last paragraph. Hopefully this cleared things up!

history.subject: homework5 #1

history.content:
Think of it this way: Given N bins and 1 ball, put the ball in a random bin. The probability of placing the ball in the kth bin will be: $$P(k) = 1/n$$.

Now we're interested in three bins (lets call them A, B, and C), each with $$P(k) = 1/n$$.

Since a ball cannot be in two bins at once, $$P(A)$$, $$P(B)$$, and $$P(C)$$ are disjoint.
Therefore $$P(A\bigcap B) = P(A\bigcap C) = P(B\bigcap C) = 0$$.

Given all this, what is $$P(A\bigcup B \bigcup C)$$? That's what the question is asking.

It's true that the probability should be the same no matter what bin it is in. But, we are looking for $$P(A \cap B \cap C) \neq P(A)$$

For this one you should think about the size of the outcome space, and the size of the event space which you want to occur. Note that the probabilities are uniformly distributed.

It's true that the probability should be the same no matter what bin it is in. But, we are looking for $$P(A \cup B \cup C) \neq P(A)$$.

For this one you should think about the size of the outcome space, and the size of the event space which you want to occur. Note that the probabilities are uniformly distributed.

history.content: <tt>For independent events (probability of A does not effect probability of B), the P({a,b}) (the probability of A or B) is just P(A) + P(B)</tt>

Benjamin's answer is not correct. Here are the correct statements:

If A and B are disjoint then P(A union B) =P(A)+P(B)

As the sets {a} and {b} are disjoint and their union is {a,b} we get that P({a,b})=P({a})+P({b})

--------

If A and B are independent then P(A intersect B) = P(A)P(B).

history.subject: HW 5 Q8 Part 7

history.content:
Short version: in the previous question, you know something extra.  The first 3 balls of the lottery have already been chosen, and none of those match your ticket.  In the following question, none of the balls have been chose.

Stated another way:
* In the previous question, only one ball remains to be drawn.  So the only outcomes to consider are choices of a single ball.  
* In the following question, the sample space includes every choice of 4 balls.

history.content:
How do you determine P(emptyset)? I understand for the ones where the union of the sets causes an addition of probabilities since the individual sets are independent, but how is P(emptyset) determined?

From what I understand, it is the intersection of {a}, {b}, and {c} which are independent, so it should have P(emptyset) = P({a}) * P({b}) * P({c}). Why is this not correct? 
#homework5
history.subject: homework5 Question6

history.content:
For any probability measure, $$P(\emptyset)$$ is 0. For a finite sample space, eg $$\Omega = {1,2,3}$$, this is easy to see:
What is $$P({1,2})$$? The sum of the probability of every outcome $$\omega \in {1,2} = P(1)+P(2)$$
$$P(\emptyset) = $$ the sum of the probability of every outcome $$\omega \in \emptyset$$. So that's the sum over no elements, which is 0.

You could say $$\emptyset = {a} \cap {b} \cap {c}$$, which would allow you to compute $$P(\emptyset)$ from $P(a), P(b), P(c)$$ *if* the events {a}, {b}, {c} were independent. 
However, the events {a}, {b}, {c} are mutually exclusive, *not* independent. Events are independent if knowing some subset of the events happened says nothing about the probability of any other other subset of the events happening. Knowing the event {a} happened, you know that the outcome of your experiment was 'a' and that the event {b} could not have happened. We'll get into more definitions of independence soon.

For any probability measure, $$P(\emptyset)$$ is 0. For a finite sample space, eg $$\Omega = {1,2,3}$$, this is easy to see:
What is $$P({1,2})$$? The sum of the probability of every outcome $$\omega \in {1,2} = P(1)+P(2)$$
$$P(\emptyset) = $$ the sum of the probability of every outcome $$\omega \in \emptyset$$. So that's the sum over no elements, which is 0.

You could say $$\emptyset = {a} \cap {b} \cap {c}$$, which would allow you to compute $$P(\emptyset)$ from $P(a), P(b), P(c)$$ *if* the events {a}, {b}, {c} were independent. 
However, the events {a}, {b}, {c} are mutually exclusive, *not* independent. Events are independent if knowing one happened says nothing about the probability of the other happening. Knowing the event {a} is true, you know that the outcome of your experiment was a and that the event {b} is not true. We'll get into more definitions of independence soon.

For any probability measure, $$P(\emptyset)$$ is 0. For a finite sample space, eg $$\Omega = {1,2,3}$$, this is easy to see:
What is $$P({1,2})$$? The sum of the probability of every outcome $$\omega \in {1,2} = P(1)+P(2)$$
$$P(\emptyset) = $$ the sum of the probability of every outcome $$\omega \in \emptyset$$. So that's the sum over no elements, which is 0.

You could say $\emptyset = {a} \cap {b} \cap {c}$, which would allow you to compute $P(\emptyset)$ from $P(a), P(b), P(c)$ *if* the events {a}, {b}, {c} were independent.  
However, the events {a}, {b}, {c} are mutually exclusive, *not* independent.  Events are independent if knowing one happened says nothing about the probability of the other happening.  Knowing the event {a} is true, you know that the outcome of your experiment was a and that the event {b} is not true.  We'll get into more definitions of independence soon.

For any probability measure, $$P(\emptyset)$$ is 0.  For a finite sample space, eg $$\Omega = {1,2,3}$$, this is easy to see:

What is $$P({1,2})$$? The sum of the probability of every outcome $$\omega \in {1,2} = P(1)+P(2)$$

$$P(\emptyset) = $$ the sum of the probability of every outcome $$\omega \in \emptyset$$.  So that's the sum over no elements, which is 0.

I couldn't do this problem without drawing it out. Draw circles, X, Y, and Z fit an entire universe of 1 but do not intersect. Draw the circle W in the middle intersecting all of these three. You will see that this question is basically asking: Find the values of all three intersections and add them up. They will add up to W So you are given:
  • <--- This means that the three circles do not intersect
  • outcome space <- This means that they occupy the entire space of1
  • <-- Label the intersection 0.1
  • <-- Label the intersection 0.2
  • <-- P(W|Z) = P(W intersect Z) / P(Z)
  • <--- Label Z 0.1

history.content: It follows that we can also derive a upper bound for the probability that all the balls are placed successfully. This upper bound is __________. Note that this is less than . history.subject: HW 5 Problem 2 last part

history.content: The event that all balls are placed successfully is the INTERSECTION of the events that the k'th ball is placed successfully. The probability of an intersection event is the product of the probabilities of the constituent events.

The event that all balls are placed successfully should be the INTERSECTION of the events that the k'th ball is placed successfully. The probability of an intersection event is the product of the probabilities of the constituent events.

I'm having trouble understanding this:

Same sample space. A={first is a heart} B={second is a 10}

Why wouldn't this be dependent? Event B can be influenced by event A if you happen to draw the 10 of hearts for event A, right? Or does that not count as affecting event B? 
#homework6
history.subject: HW 6 Problem 10

history.content: I was thinking the same thing. There is a 13/52 chance you draw a heart but also a 1/13 chance that heart is a 10. Wouldnt this situation cause the second events probability to go from 4/51 to 3/51?

You need to compute the probabilities of
1) Getting a heart in the first draw.
2) Getting a 10 in the second draw (which is equal to the prob of getting a 10 in the first draw)
3) Getting a heart in the first draw AND getting a 10 in the second draw.

If P(A and B) = P(A)*P(B) then the events are independent.

I wrote a detailed solution for problem 10, please read it and let me know, here, on Piazza, if you have any questions.  Yoav

#hw8 #fixed_point #5
history.subject: hw8 #5

history.content:
Yes, it is pretty obvious from symmetry. In more detail:

$$X_i=1$$ if i is in the i'th bin (i is a fixed point), otherwise $$X_i=0$$.
As we are using a random permutation i has probability 1/n of falling into each of the n bins. In particular, it has probability i of falling in bin i.
Therefor we have $$E(X_i)=0*P(Xi=0)+1*P(X_i=1)=1/n$$

Hint says use the strategy from previous question.

#3 #hw8
history.subject: hw8 #3

history.content:
Problem 2 (the previous question) says that the expected number of iterations before a success, in this case all three elements happening together on the same day, is denoted by 1/p, where p is the probability of some repeatable experiment producing a successful outcome.

So now given the above strategy from the previous question Problem 2, you should be able to solve the problem given that p is 5/180, the probability that all three elements happen together.

Hi, the problem is that $$P(X_{i} = i + 1) = Pr(X_{i} = i)$$ is not true for all i, only for $$0 \leq i &lt; n$$. You can easily see this by thinking about the random variable itself, $$Y_{i}$$, which is supposed to be 1 if the ith position is the value $$i + 1$$. However, if you have a permutation for numbers 1 ... n, there won't be any spot which has the value $$n + 1$$. 

Hope that helps

history.content: That is not the correct formula to use. To solve for the mean you use Z = 3X + 4Y + 2 combined with E(aX + b) = aE(X) + b. To solve for var you use Z = 3X + 4Y + 2 with var(aX + b) = a^2var(X).

history.content:
For others who may need help too..

You can use $$var(aX + b) = a^2var(X)$$

In this case, since there are two variables, we have $$var(aX + bY + c)$$ but from the given formula we can change that to be $$var(aX + bY)$$ since as we see, adding a constant doesn't change the variance. Now, we know that X and Y are independent so aX and bY are also independent. Using independence, we would have $$var(aX + bY) = var(aX) + var(bY)$$ and finally using the first formula, we'll get $$var(aX) + var(bY) = a^2var(X) + b^2var(Y)$$

Hope that helped

This is a puzzle that came to me from playing an online game, an I am wondering if you guys could help me solve it.

In this game, there are 2 teams (team blue and team red) with 1 to 6 players. Each player can pick one of 8 characters for battle. There can be more than one of the same character on the team or none of that character on that team. My question is, what is the probability that 2 randomly chosen teams happen to match, i.e. have the same characters on both teams.

For the 1v1 case, the answer is 1/8
For the 2v2 case, the answer is
P(same character on blue)*P(match)+P(Different characters)*P(match)=(1*1/8)(1/8*1/8)+(1*7/8)(2/8*1/8)=15/256

These teams are small and I calculated these by hand, but what is the general case solution where n is the number of players on a team (nvn)?

It is not (1/8)^n, not 7!(n-7!)/n! (in other words 1/number of teams), nor is it n!/8^n. I have tried this problem by hand for 2 days and could really use some help.

history.subject: Probability Puzzle

history.content:
just to be sure I understand correctly:

1. k v k means two teams with k players each. and k is between 1 and 6
2. The assumption is that each player chooses one of the 8 characters independently at random.


OK, now that this is clear. Here is how I suggest approaching the problem.

Say m is the number of different characters.

The sample space is the choice of each player. As each player has m choices the size of this space is $$m^{2k}$$

Next, we need to find the number of choice-vectors such that the two teams match.

First, let's solve the problem for the case where there are two characters, i.e. m=2. In this case one number suffices to characterize the
distribution: the number of character 1 and the number of character 2. Lets call those i and k-i. The number of choice-vectors
that satisfy this in a single team is $${k \choose i}$$. Therefor the number of choice vectors for both teams is 

$$\sum_{i=0}^{k} {k \choose i}^2$$

If this is clear, the next step is to consider larger values of m.

I believe this can be done using a binary encoding of the 8 characters (luckily, a power of 2. It can be done for general m, but it will become messy).

0: 000
1: 001
2: 010
3: 011
4: 100
5: 101
6: 110
7: 111

So now consider the choice made by each player as a sequence of 3 binary choices: first bit, then second bit, then third bit. ....

Work on it... I'l help you more as you advance.

2. The assumption is that each player chooses one of the 8 characters independently at random.

Thanks for responding professor! I understand the first part with m=2. I understand that the summation is going through how to place the i duplicates (if that makes sense) and that the probability is that sum over m^(2k). However I have no idea how making the character selection a binary choice will help.

I was thinking that I could represent all the character choices (such as 5,3,0,2) with the binary representation (101,011,000,010), but how can I check if the teams match? I can't just say they match if they have the same number of 0's and 1's.

Think of it as a sequence of three choices for each player. First, each player decides between characters {1,2,3,4} and {5,6,7,8}.
Then all the players that chose {1,2,3,4} choose between {1,2} and {3,4} etc.

Define M(k,m) to be the number of different choice vectors that correspond to k players (on each team) and m characters to choose from.
You can write a recursive formula that expresses M(n,k) as a function of M(n',k') for (n',k') smaller than (n,k).

Think about it.
Ok thanks!
Yes that is correct.

history.content:
It is not always the case that E(XY) = E(X)E(Y). This is only the case when X,Y are uncorrelated. 

Since you aren't sure whether X,Y are correlated yet, you need to go through every possibility in the contingency table to make this computation. Eg in problem 5:
P(X=1,Y=1)*1*1 + P(X=1,Y=2)*1*2 + P(X=1,Y=3)*1*3 + P(X=2,Y=1)*2*1...

This is E(XY) directly from the definition of expectation

It is not always the case that E(XY) = E(X)E(Y). This is only the case when X,Y are uncorrelated. 

Since you aren't sure whether X,Y are correlated yet, you need to go through every possibility in the contingency table to make this computation. Eg in problem 5:
P(X=1,Y=1)*1*1 + P(X=1,Y=2)*1*2 + P(X=1,Y=3)*1*3 + P(X=2,Y=1)*2*1...

It is not always the case that E(XY) = E(X)E(Y).  This is only the case when X,Y are uncorrelated.  

Since you aren't sure whether X,Y are correlated yet, you need to go through every possibility in the contingency table to make this computation.  Eg in problem 5:

history.content:
What is $$P(X_i=0)$$?

What is the probability the first ball misses bin $$i$$? What is the probability the second ball misses? The bin the first ball ends up in is completely unrelated to the bin the second ball ends up in, so the events telling where the first and second ball end up are independent. Recall for independent events $$A,B,C$$, $$P(A,B,C)=P(A)P(B)P(C)$$. Thus you can decompose the probability *every* ball misses as the product of the probabilities that each ball misses bin $$i$$. 


What is $$P(X_i=1)$$?
What is the probability the first ball lands in bin $$i$$, and the rest of the balls miss. The computation of this probability follows a very similar pattern to the computation for $$P(X_i=0)$$. 
What is the probability the second ball lands ... " ... "
What is the probability the third ball lands ... " ... "

What is the probability that any of the above happen? The events are disjoint, so we can sum the probabilities to get this result.

We learned that X and Y are independent if E(XY ) = E(X)E(Y ).

In this case, E(X) is 2 and E(Y) is 2, and E(XY) is 4, so that's satisfied.

So, why are they not independent?  
#homework10 #1
history.subject: hw10 #1

history.content:
Hi, while it is true that if E(XY) = E(X) * E(Y) then X and Y are independent, this is not an if and only if statement. So, if we know they are independent, we can draw the conclusion that E(XY) = E(X) * E(Y), however knowing that E(XY) = E(X) * E(Y) is not enough to know they are independent. 

Edit: Actually I just realized I've been reading this incorrectly. Sorry guys! I removed the incorrect part just so if anyone else reads it they won't get the wrong information too.

What I maintained is true, although as someone else pointed out, I believe they should indeed by independent. I'll let the professor and TAs know.

If you look at P(X=2), you will see that $$P(X=2 | Y=1) &lt; P(X=2 | Y=2)$$ so by definition they can not be independent. Hope that clears things up!

But I think the question is asking, "how many pairs of i and j are there such that i != j?" i and j are both points between 1 and n.
Check out the discussion in this thread https://piazza.com/class#fall2012/cse103/172

Let's phrase the question a little differently:

1) How many pairs of  integers i,j are there where $$1\leq i \leq n, 1 \leq j \leq n$$  ?

2) How many pairs of integers i,j are there were $$1\leq i \leq n, 1 \leq j \leq n$$   and $$i \neq j$$  ?


The answer to (2) is the answer to the question above.

#homework10
history.subject: homework10

history.content:
Suppose $$X,Y$$ are random variables which map to the integers.

They are independent if for all integers i,j   $$P(X=i \mbox{ and } Y=j) = P(X=i) P(Y=j)$$

In words - knowing the value of X has no effect on the distribution of Y and vice versa.

X and Y are identically distributed if for every integer i  $$P(X=i)=P(Y=i)$$

In words - X and Y have the same distribution.

Formula: var(X) = E(X^2) - (E(X))^2


We know that Tij can be 0 or 1, so 
E(Tij) = 0*Pr(Tij=0) + 1*Pr(Tij=1)


Therefore,
E(Tij^2) = (0^2)*Pr(Tij=0) + (1^2)*Pr(Tij=1)

After that, figuring out E(Tij)^2 and thus var(Tij) should be a breeze

history.content: Here us an explanation for why the covariance in example 1 is 1. First, consider the marginals: the distribution of X is uniform: P(X=1)=P(X=2)=P(X=3)=P(X=4)=1/4 The distribution of Y is uniform over 1 and 3: P(Y=1)=P(Y=3)=1/2, P(Y=2)=0 So far so good? OK, from these it is easy to get the E(X)=2.5 and E(Y)=2 now, the definition of the covariance is: $$cov(X,Y)=E[(X-E(X))(Y-E(Y))]$$ Which in our case is $$cov(X,Y)=E[(X-2.5)(Y-2)]$$ To compute this expectation we take the sum of the probability of each outcome times the value of the product corresponding to that outcome. So consider the upper left corner entry, corresponding to X=1,Y=1. This case has probability 1/4 (same as the other 3 non-zero entries) and we get the first term: $$(1/4)((1-2.5)(1-2))=(-1.5*-1)$$ #Covariance
history.subject: Explanation of calculation of covariance

history.content:
Here us an explanation for why the covariance in example 1 is 1.

First, consider the marginals: the distribution of X is uniform: P(X=1)=P(X=2)=P(X=3)=P(X=4)=1/4
The distribution of Y is uniform over 1 and 3: P(Y=1)=P(Y=3)=1/2, P(Y=2)=0

So far so good?

OK, from these it is easy to get the E(X)=2.5 and E(Y)=2

now, the definition of the covariance is:   $$cov(X,Y)=E[(X-E(X))(Y-E(Y))]$$

Which in our case is $$cov(X,Y)=E[(X-2.5)(Y-2)]$$

To compute this expectation we take the sum of the probability of each outcome times the value of the product corresponding to that
outcome. So consider the upper left corner entry, corresponding to X=1,Y=1. This case has probability 1/4 (same as the other 3 non-zero entries)
and we get the first term:
$$(1/4)((1-2.5)(1-2))=(-1.5*-1)$$

children.subject:
Here it looks like you're computing E( XY - E(XY)) = E(XY) - E(XY) = 0 directly from the definition:

P(X=1,Y=1)( 1*1 - E(XY)) + P(X=1,Y=3)( 1*3 - E(XY)) ...

This not covariance though- it will be 0 no matter what. Covariance is E( (X-E(X)) * (Y-E(Y)) ). You can compute this in a similar manner to the way you proceeded:
P(X=1,Y=1)( (1-E(X))*(1-E(Y)) ) + P(X=1,Y=3)...

Or you can take the algebraically (but maybe not conceptually) easier route: 
E( (X-E(X)) * (Y-E(Y)) ) = E(XY) - E(X)E(Y)

(1/3)(1-13/3)+(1/6)(3-13/3)+(1/6)(3-13/3)+(1/3)(9-13/3)

Where 13/3 is E(XY)

Think of XY as a new random variable, call it Z=XY

You compute the expected value of Z using the standard definition of expectation:  $$E(Z)=\sum_{i=-\infty}^{\infty} i P(Z=i)$$

As Z=XY you can rewrite that as

$$E(XY)=\sum_{i=-\infty}^{\infty}\sum_{j=-\infty}^{\infty} ij P(X=i,Y=j)$$

Which means you sum the term for each combination of i and j such that P(X=1,Y=j)&gt;0

How many of the 6 card faces you could see are diamonds? Of these, how many have back sides that are spades? There you have the answer.  You answered something similar in the second bullet.

when you play the first time, you bet a dollar and if you win you get 2 dollar so the net gain is 2-1=1.

#homework11 #5
history.subject: Homework 11 Problem 5 Corr(X,Y)

history.content:
The COV(XY) = E(XY) / E(X)E(y)    ------ Not True, which you can easily see because it would imply that when X,Y are independent E(XY)=E(X) E(Y) so COV(X,Y)=1, which should be 0 instead.

The correct equation is: COV(X,Y) = E[(X-E(X)) (Y-E(Y))] = E(XY)-E(X)E(Y)
The COV(XY) = E(XY) / E(X)E(y)

history.subject: Hw1 #1a

history.content:
Hi, the reason it is not the union is the union is satisfied by either one of them being true, which means that if both the second and most qualified candidates are in the last n - r candidates, then this would be true. However, that alone is not sufficient to ensure that she picks the most qualified candidate since if she meets the second most qualified candidate first, then the most qualified one would not be picked.

$$P(B|A)$$ would be correct if you could assume the event A happens, but we can't.

Um no I don't think that's quite right. So the CDF $$F(x) = P(X \leq x)$$ which is not necessarily 1.

That's also why the CDF goes to 1 as x approaches infinite. However, that doesn't mean $$P(x &gt; 25) = F(25)$$. In fact, it's the opposite, $$F(25) = P(x \leq 25)$$

Remember: $$P(a &lt; x \leq b) = P(x \leq b) - P(x \leq a)$$

Hi Everybody,

Looking at the grades overall, most people are doing very well, which is great.

However, there are some people that are struggling a little bit (about 20 students out of 140 have an average of 8.0 or lower on the HW)
If you are one of these people, it is very important that you get help from your group. This can happen both inside and outside class
and it works best if it is 1-1. When two of the students in a group are much stronger than the others, these two will tend to talk among them
and give the answer to the others as a matter of fact. Ideally there is are just two people in each team, in which case it is easier for the weaker student
to talk and for the stronger student to help them.

I highly recommend that groups that have 4 students and 1-2 of them have an average lower than 8.0 break into two teams of two, each team with at most one weak person.

If you team has 3 people and one of them is struggling, then my recommendation is that that one site between the two stronger people, rather than to one side.

I don't think there is a team of 3 people where 2 or more are struggling. If there is, please let me know, we will have to do some reshuffling of teams.

On another note, there has been very little activity on the test-preparation problems. Please start doing them so that we can find out which areas you are having difficulty with and
I still have enough time to help you.

A test-preparation question (and a question in the final) are very different from the HW questions because you get only one chance.

Yoav

What does this equal? I know what E(X2j) equals and E(XjXj') but how do I go from here? Don't really get the question 
#homework13
history.subject: HW13 #1

history.content:
Sum  $$E \left(X^{2}_{j} \right) $$ over all possible values of j.  There are n values of j.

Sum  $$E \left(X_{j} X_{j'} \right) $$ over all possible values of j $$\ne$$ j'. You have n choices for the first j, then you have n-1 choices that aren't the same for j'

Add these values together. Tada!

children.subject: Thanks for your help! How do you sum E(xjxj') over all possible values of j not equal to j'? I don't really understand what j and j' stand for

j and j' simply differentiate between any two possible values of j, so when we say j != j', we mean: considering any two j values, we want the cases where they are not the same.
as stated in the answer above, you have n choices for the first j, and n-1 for j', given that only one j can equal itself. Multiply those together and put it over the expected value of a single E(XjXj'). that's the sum over all j!=j' of E(XjXj').

history.content:
Nope, the question is correct as stated. It's a little tricky. 

Here's the approach I would take:
1. Get the answers for the point masses, these are the easy ones. Imagine the graph with these masses removed. 
2. There should now be three parts to the graph with 3 different slopes. These 3 parts correspond to the uniform distributions and their overlap.  The uniform distributions overlap on [1,2].  
3. Get the slopes of the two lines (the densities of the uniform distributions) from the part where they don't overlap. 

***For those seeking a better understanding of summing density functions:
You can sum density functions. Let's say we had a uniform on [0,1] of density 1/2, and a uniform on [0.5,1.5] of density 1/2. 
The summed density function would be:
[0,0.5] has density 1/2. [0.5,1] has density 1. [1,1.5] has density 1/2
The cdf:
0 =&gt; 0
0.5 =&gt; 0.25 = prev + (segment length)*density = 0 + (0.5-0)*1/2
1 =&gt; 0.75 = 0.25 + (1-0.5)*1
1.5 =&gt; 1.00 = 0.75 + (1.5-1)*1/2

history.content:
(0.6)^19 * (0.4) is the probability of one specific permutation of 19H/1T. for instance: 19 heads in a row followed by 1 tail. But it doesn't matter when the tail comes up, as long as it's only once. 

in other words, you need to multiply your answer by the number of possible permutations, which is (n choose k).

The definition of erf in this link is a weird one. Most of other sources define erf as http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Error_function. 

What you just found out about the need to multiply by 2 is right though. "erf" is calculated as twice the SIGNED area of a region from the mean. It is positive if the region is to the right of mean, and negative if it is to the left of mean. 

Also note that erf is not based on a STANDARD normal distribution (zero-mean with variance 1), instead it is based on a normal with variance 1/2, so erf(z) does not compute the tail of a standard normal curve starting at value z. On the wikipedia page you will find how to relate erf to $$\Phi$$ or Q function, which directly calculates the region under a standard normal curve.
The way I did it is just by integrating the normal density function, which is tedious and time consuming, but it works.

history.subject: HW 14 #2 Last part

history.content:
The total round-off error is a sum of the individual i.i.d. errors. By Central Limit Theorem, the total error can be approximated with a normal distribution.
This question asks for the probability that the total error is greater than 3.
The two tails have nothing to do with (-.5, .5), which is where the individual error is distributed.
Rather, the one tail is the region under the normal curve for X > 3, and the other tail is the opposite, region under the curve for X < -3.

I personally like to use Q function, or its complement $$\Phi = 1-Q$$, instead of erf. Once you have the z-score, you just need to plug it into Q function and you got the probability of the tail.

Note that erf is the function that the professor expects you to learn. All three of Q,$$\Phi$$ and erf serve the same purpose, that is to calculate the area under a normal curve, and it is easy to convert between each other. You will find the formulae for the conversion on the wikipedia link that I put in the instructor note.

Essentially, Q function calculates the area of the tail of a standard normal distribution, and $$\Phi$$ calculates the head; erf(x) is twice the area from mean to x under a zero-mean normal distribution with variance 1/2. erf(x) is positive if the area is to the right of the mean. erf(x) is negative if the area is to the left of the mean. 

The z-score of a value on a non-standard normal distribution is basically its counterpart on a standard normal distribution. So you can directly plug z-score into Q or $$\Phi$$, but not erf. You can, however, plug z-score/sqrt(2) into erf to fit the normal distribution with variance 1/2 on which erf is defined.

You can get the value of these functions using http://www.wolframalpha.com/.

history.content:
You can use "erf" in the answer (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Error_function). You do not have to give an numeric result.

You may also use $$\Phi$$ (i.e. the CDF of a standard normal distribution) by writing "Phi", or Q function (i.e. the complement of $$\Phi$$, the tail of a standard normal, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q_function) by writing "Q" in the answer. They serve the same purpose as erf, which is to calculate the area under part of a normal distribution. You are not required to learn these two functions, but if you already know what they are, you can use them in your answer as well. 

The three functions can be related using the following formulae:
$$\Phi(x) = \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{2}\text{erf}(x/\sqrt{2})$$
$$Q(x) = \frac{1}{2} - \frac{1}{2}\text{erf}(x/\sqrt{2})$$

If you would like to have a numeric answer, http://www.wolframalpha.com/ computes the value of these functions for you.

#homework14 #4
history.subject: hw 14 #4

history.content:
As the sample size increases, the sample mean has less and less variability (i.e. smaller variance). One way to think about that is if the sample size is so large that it equals the size of the population, then every time you do the sampling, you get the same sample mean (which is exactly the population mean), and there is no variance at all.

Specifically, for n samples of a random variable with sd $$\sigma$$, the sample mean's sd becomes $$\sigma/\sqrt{n}$$.

children.subject:
Hi, so that is true only for this specific type of problem, the type being where you have n independent events all with probability p. 

You can set this up as each random variable $$X_i$$ being 1 if $$X_i$$ is "true" and 0 if "false", although true or false can really be anything. In this case, we are saying it's 1 if the monkey got the question i right.

We can easily see that $$E[X_i] = p * 1 + (1-p) * 0 = p$$ and $$E[X_i^2] = p$$. Thus, $$var[X_i] = p - p^2 = p(1-p)$$. 

Then, we know $$X_i$$ are independent for different i, so  $$var[\sum X_i] = \sum var[X_i] = n * var[X_i] = n * p(1-p)$$. However, we also know that $$E[\sum X_i] = n * p$$ so we can substitute that in and get 
$$var[\sum X_i] = E[\sum X_i] * (1-p)$$.

Feel free to ask any questions if something doesn't make sense.
Hi, I used mean*(1-probability) and got the correct answer, but can you please explain why this is correct?  Like op, I tried to figure out E(X^2) and I couldn't get it.

history.content:
Hi, I don't think it's wise to figure out $$E[X^2}$$ directly in this case. Although if you wanted to, you could, it's just that it would be a tedious amount of calculation. But just in case it comes up useful later, I'll explain it briefly.

So to find $$E[X]$$, you find $$\sum_{i} p_i * x_i$$ for all possible values of $$x_i$$ and where $$p_i$$ represents the $$P(X = x_i)$$. To find $$E[X^2]$$, you basically do the same thing except that you have $$x_i^2$$: 
$$E[X^2] = \sum_{i} p_i * x_i^2$$ for the same $$x_i$$ and $$p_i$$.

The way I did it was that I considered $$X_i$$ to be the random variable representing whether the monkey got question i right. So, $$X_i = 1$$ when the monkey gets it right, and $$X_i = 0$$ when wrong. 

Then, since all $$X_i$$ are independent for differing i, we can just find $$var(X_i)$$ which are equal for all i, and then take the sum. So, $$var(X) = \sum_{i=1}^{k} var(X_i) = k * var(X_i)$$ and so to get the standard deviation we just take the square root of that.

history.content:
So, consider the random variable $$X_i$$ which represents weight for woman i. $$E[X_i] = \mu$$. Now consider the random variable $$Y$$ which represents the mean of all $$X_i$$. $$E[Y] = \sum_{i=1}^{n} E[X_i] / n = \mu$$ where n is the number of women are we choosing. 

Now to find the standard deviation, we first calculate the variance. $$var[X_i] = \sigma$$. But we want the variance of Y, which is 
$$var[Y] = var[\sum X_i/n] = \sum var[X_i /n] = \sum var[X_i]/n^2 = var[X_i]/n$$. Then taking the square root we get $$\sqrt{var[X_i]/n$$. 

Finally, the Z score for Y would be $$\frac{x - \mu}{\sqrt{var[X_i]/n}}$$.

I believe your question is asking the probability of being between 123 and 168.
When you look up a chart to find the probability values for a certain z-score, you should pay attention to whether the chart is calculating the CDF or 1-CDF, namely whether it is calculating from -infty to z, or from z to infty.
Usually it is the CDF case. In this case if you want to find the probability between 123 and 168, you need to subtract CDF at 168 by the CDF at 123.

history.content:
You are right, that is the way to get the exact answer. For a good approximation you can use the normal  approximation to the binomial distribution.
Just calculate the mean and the std, find the appropriate Z-value and consult the table.

Hi, I'm not sure if you just didn't write out the full question, but doing 1 - (P(winning 8) + P(winning 7) + ... + P(winning 0)) is the probability for winning at least 9 times, not the probability of winning 9 times.

But perhaps you did want the probability of winning at least 9 times. I'm not sure if I understand the question correctly, but it sounds like you are playing some card game 24 times and you want to win 9 times. However, the probability of winning time $$i$$ is independent of time $$j$$ for $$i \neq j$$. So you could calculate the probability of winning a single time and then using the binomial distribution.

At this point you would still have to do what you said, that is taking the sum of the probabilities, but if you don't need to know the exact solution then there is an upper bound on the CDF of the binomial distribution. 

Perhaps someone else can give a better answer though since this isn't something I've encountered.

But, using the Q function is recommended. In case you forgot, the standard normal is a normal with mean 0 and standard deviation 1. Also, remember that Q gives you the right tail and think about how to use that to find the portion it's asking you for. 

Good luck!

children.subject: Nope you can't just plug in 2.575 to that. Think about what part of the distribution Q measures and what part it is asking you for.

If you plug in (2*Q(2.575)) you get a probability of something close to .01.  

2*(Q(2.575)) effectively calculates P when Y&gt;2.575 and Y&lt;-2.575.

This makes sense because the area of the distribution that's outside 2.575 standard deviations from the center of the graph would be really, really tiny.  On the other hand, the area of the graph within 2.575 standard deviations from the center would be really, really large. 

So...to get Q(-2.575&lt;=Y&lt;=2.575)...

history.content:
From the "Sheet of Useful Facts":

$$
stddev\left( \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} X_i \right) = \frac{stddev(X_i)}{\sqrt{n}}
$$

p is probability that they are spotted. history.content:
Here is how I approached it, using part 1 as the example:

"Suppose that for a given data set of D, a 95 % confidence interval is calculated to be (-3.45,1.78)" is basically saying that there is a 95% chance that that any particular element of D has a value between -3.45 and 1.78. An element in D is basically just the difference between an element in X and an element in Y. The null hypothesis is that the difference between an element in X and an element in Y is 0. Well, for this part, we are 95% certain that the difference between an element in X and an element in Y is between -3.45 and 1.78, and 0 falls within that range. I followed the same reasoning for the next two parts.

Basically, your hunches and your googles give the right answers. Let me try to explain this. We are sampling data from a distribution with some unknown mean $$\mu$$. The null hypothesis that we want to reject is that $$\mu=0$$ We take a sample from the distribution and compute from it an X% confidence interval $$[a,b]$$. Note that a confidence interval is a random variable - it will come out differently for different samples. The meaning of a %X confidence interval is that with probability (at least) X/100 the true mean is inside the interval - $$a\leq\mu\leq b$$ In other words, if the interval does not contain 0 (or any other fixed number) then the conclusion from getting the %X confidence interval is that the null hypothesis is rejected with significance (100-X)% I hope this makes sense. We will go over it again in class on wed.

children.subject:
Hi, so the z value is just a measure of how many standard deviations away from the mean you are. 

Now to understand its relation to the significance level, consider the the normal distribution. For any value of z, we can separate the normal distribution into the right and left part. So for $$z = 0$$, the area under the right and left parts of the distribution would be exactly 0.5 for the standard normal distribution(standard normal has mean 0, std dev 1). The significance level is the area under the right tail for $$z &gt; 0$$, and the area under the left tail for $$z &lt; 0$$. 

So for parts 1 and 2, it's asking you for what value of z would you get $$\alpha$$ under the left tail and then under the right tail respectively. For part 3, it's asking you to consider both $$\pm z$$. So, in this case, you have two z values, and it's asking you to find z so that the combined area of the right and left tail is equal to $$\alpha$$
Got it!! Thx!!
You're very welcome!
I am confused with the first part..could you tell me the relation between significance level and z value?thx!

Hi, the left tail value should actually just be $$\alpha$$, and same for the right tail.

I think you are a little bit confused as to what Qinv(x) does, so let me try to explain it to you. So, for any z score we can separate the normal distribution into the right and left portion, or tail. Q(z) is typically what we call the area under the right tail, and $$\phi(x)$$ is typically what we call the area of the left. 

With that in mind, Qinv(x) is the inverse of Q(z), so instead of taking a z score and giving you the area under the right tail, it instead takes the area under the right tail and gives you back the z score which would give you that area.

Hopefully that makes sense to you. So to find the tails, the left and right tail values are actually just $$\alpha$$. So, all you need to do is use the Qinv(x) function to get the z scores associated with those values. Note that when using Qinv(x), it's always expecting the area under the right tail, so if you want the z score associated with a significance level for something that's not the right tail, you'll have to find what the area under the right tail is, or use symmetry if possible. 

In case it still doesn't make sense to you, I'll walk you through the first one and hopefully you can use it as an example to solve the other ones. if you get it though, ignore the rest of this post entirely as it would be much better for you to work this out on your own. 

So for the first problem, it's asking you for the z value which would give you the significance level of $$\alpha$$ under the left tail. We know that Qinv(x) gives you the z score corresponding to area x under the right tail, but it's asking for the left. We know though, that the area under the entire normal curve is always 1, so if the area under the left tail is 0.02, we can find the area under the right tail, which is $$1 - 0.02 = 0.98$$. So, we can take Qinv(0.98) to find the answer. 

While this is an easy way to do it, there is an even easier way to do it which involves no calculation and in my opinion shows a stronger understanding. You want the area under the left tail to be 0.02, but you know that the normal distribution is symmetric around the mean. Well, we can easily find z for 0.02 significance level under the right tail, which is Qinv(0.02), and we know that the normal is symmetric, so the z value for 0.02 significance under the left tail is just $$- Qinv(0.02)$$

However I think you are a little bit confused. Let me just lay them all out on the table since it can be a little bit confusing.
Alpha refers some area under the graph.
z refers to a number of standard deviations away from the mean, so a certain value on the distribution.
Q(z) returns the area under the tail to the right of z.
Qinv(x) returns the z value with the area under the right tail of z that is x.

So, z and alpha are referring to totally different things. z is a value on the distribution, while alpha is the area under the right tail. You can think that for every value z, there is a right tail with some area. What we want, is z so that the right tail is alpha/2.

Consider Qinv(x) by itself. This gives you the z value which has area x under the right tail. If you multiply this by 2, what you get is another z value, but you really have no idea what the area under this new value is at all(unless of course you look it up). 

I'll try to walk you through this. So, we've established that we want a total of $$\alpha$$ under the two tails right? Then we said that since they are symmetric, we want each tail to have $$\alpha/2$$.

Now, all we need is the z value which has area $$\alpha/2$$ under the right tail. We know that -z also has area $$\alpha/2$$ under the left tail by symmetry. So what is the z value with $$\alpha/2$$ under the right tail? (Hint: use Qinv)

history.content:
Hi, so the p value is similar to alpha except that alpha is just a constant while the p value is not. For this part, the problem gives you some z score, and it wants to know what p value would reject this test. 

Before what we did was give you alpha, which you can think of as some predetermined p value if you want, and then ask you if a test rejects for some given z score. What did you do? Well presumably you just looked at the table of Z scores or used the Q function, and then saw if the area under the tail was smaller than alpha, and if it was, you rejected. 

Now we are just asking you to do the same thing but backwards, we give you the z score, and ask you what p score, which you can think of it as having a random variable for alpha, will the test reject? So again you should look at the table, and then look at the area under the tail, and that would give you what p value you will reject for. 

I hope that makes sense!

So when I said the area under the tail, I meant Q(z). So I'm sure you know this by now, but you can think of the z score as a value  which separates the normal distribution into the left and right sides. We consider the tail to be the smaller of the two areas, so if z is positive then it will be to the right and if z is negative it will be to the left. 

Just for a bit, let's think about the normal distribution itself. What is it? Well, it's actually a continuous probability distribution! if you remember from before, that means that the area of the normal under $$a \leq x \leq b = P(a \leq x \leq b)$$. 

If we think about it in terms of the area of the tail then, that's basically $$P(x \ge z)$$ (assuming positive z). In other words, the area under the tail is the probability that you find something which is greater than or equal to z, under the null hypothesis.

In this particular problem, what we want to reject is the null hypothesis: seat belts don't help prevent fatalities.

Hi, I see that you've gotten it, but I'm going to post the explanation because it's really important that you understand this going forward; I don't think we're going to test you on this again until the final but I'm sure the things you learn in the future will build on this.

$$p * (1-p)$$ is the variance when you have a binary random variable $$X_i$$. However, in this case it's asking you for the variance of $$X = \sum_{i=1}^n X_i$$. The reason it is $$np(1-p)$$ is because
$$var(X) = var(\sum_{i=1}^n X_i) = \sum_{i=1}^n var(X_i) = \sum_{i=1}^n p*(1-p) = n * p(1-p)$$

#HW18
history.subject: HW18 #2 finding var(C)

history.content:
Short Answer $$p(1-p)/n$$ Long Answer
  • Don't forget, $$C = (C_1 + C_2 + ...C_n)/n$$.
  • *If* we had $$D = C_1 + C_2 + ...C_n$$. Since $$C_i$$ are independent,
$$var(D) = var( \sum_i{C_i}) = \sum_i{var(C_i)} = n var(C_i) = n p(1-p)$$
  • *But*, we don't. So:
$$var(C) = var(\frac{1}{n}\sum_i{C_i}) = \frac{1}{n^2}var(\sum_i{C_i}) = \frac{1}{n^2}n var(C_i) = \frac{1}{n}p(1-p)$$

Short Answer $$p(1-p)/n$$ Long Answer Don't forget, $$C = (C_1 + C_2 + ...C_n)/n$$. *If* we had $$D = C_1 + C_2 + ...C_n$$. Since $$C_i$$ are independent, $$var(D) = var( \sum_i{C_i}) = \sum_i{var(C_i)} = n var(C_i) = n p(1-p)$$ *But*, we don't. So $$var(C) = var(\frac{1}{n}\sum_i{C_i}) = \frac{1}{n^2}var(\sum_i{C_i}) = \frac{1}{n^2}n var(C_i) = \frac{1}{n}p(1-p)$$

Short Answer $$p(1-p)/n$$ Long Answer Don't forget, $$C = (C_1 + C_2 + ...C_n)/n$$. *If* we had $$D = C_1 + C_2 + ...C_n$$. Since $$C_i$$ are independent, $$var(D) = var( \sum_i{C_i}) = \sum_i{var(C_i)} = n*var(C_i) = n*p(1-p)$$ *But*, we don't. So $$var(C) = var((1/n)*\sum_i{C_i}) = 1/n^2*var(\sum_i{C_i}) = 1/n^2*n*var(C_i) = (1/n)*p*(1-p)$$

Short Answer $$p(1-p)/n$$ Long Answer Don't forget, $$C = (C_1 + C_2 + ...C_n)/n$$. *If* we had $$D = C_1 + C_2 + ...C_n$$. Since $$C_i$$ are independent, $$var(D) = var( \sum_i{C_i}) = \sum_i{var(C_i)} = n*var(C_i) = n*p(1-p)$$

history.content:
Hi, you can't just manipulate your old answer because it's a function of n. You need to consider every possible i to get the expected value. 

I'm going to assume you got the answer to the cost to find element i, and I'll go ahead and call this $$t_i$$. 

It's told you that the distribution is uniform, so we can assume that each of the possible choices for i happen with $$p = 1/n$$. Then, we can just use the formula for expected value, $$E[X] = \sum_x P[X = x] * x$$ for x all possibilities of X. Well, the x's in this case are all the possible times. 

Using that, we get the formula, 
$$\sum_{i=1}^n (1/n) * t_i$$ 
and I'll leave it up to you to simplify it. 

Does that make sense?

history.content:
The a could be any value &gt; 0.  So that was simply a restatement of Chebyshev's inequality.  

You will pick a convenient value of a that solves your problem.  In this case: the mean of C is 3/4, and you want to make sure C &gt;= 1/2.  Ensuring P(|C - 3/4| &gt;= 1/4) is small accomplishes this, since with high probability |C - 3/4| &lt;= 1/4 and thus C &gt;= 1/2 with high probability.

history.content:
The problem is using a=1/5.  You want Y &gt;= 1/2 with high probability, and |Y - 4/5| &lt;= 4/5-1/2 = 3/10 with high probability gets this.  

Yes, you could get Y &gt;= 1/2 by ensuring |Y - 4/5| &lt;= 1/5 with high probability, but this is stronger than you need.  You're requiring Y be even closer to 4/5 than you really need it to be: you're actually ensuring Y &gt;= 3/5 with high probability.

history.content:
Hi, so I assume you've solved the previous parts already, and we can consider the cost to lookup element(what you got in part 6) to be $$E(X_i)$$. 

The question says you can assume the distribution of lookups is uniform, which would mean that each i happens with $$P = 1/n$$. 

By the definition of expected value over discrete values then, we have
$$E[X] = \sum_i^n P(X = X_i) * E[X_i]$$

Since the homework is closed anyway, I'll just plug it in. From the previous part, we have $$E[X_i] = i/k + k/2$$ and we also know $$P(X=X_i) = 1/n$$ for all i. We can substitute these in to get
$$E[X] = \sum_i^n 1/n * (i/k + k/2)$$
$$E[X] = \sum_i^n ( i/(kn) + k/(2n) ) = \sum_i^n i/(kn) + \sum_i^n k/(2n) $$
$$= (n(n+1)/2 * 1/kn) + (n * k/(2n)) = (n+1)/(2k) + k/2$$


Please let me know if there is still any confusion.

history.content: First, hash functions are not affected by what words have been hashed in the hash table or what bits are set. They are functions that take the word you are going to store in the hash table as the only input, and output k bits that will be set to 1 if they are not already 1. Second, all the hash functions are random, which means each function can hash a word to any bit, independent of each other. Different hash functions may hash to the same bit, but it is OK, just set this bit to 1. Now, the first question asks what is the probability that a certain hash function hashes a word not to a certain bit. The second question is asking for the probability that the case in question 1 happens to all k hash functions and all n words that have already been hashed in the table. Then the third question asks the complement of question 2, i.e. what is the probability of a certain bit does get set to 1, after hashing the n words. For a new word, we need to query not just one bit, but k bits that all the k functions may hash this new word to. Question 4 asks the probability that all these k bits are set to 1, which is easy given the answer for question 3.

The first question is an easy one. By our assumption of the hash functions being random, each hash function may hash a word to any bit. For a new word, we need to query not just one bit, but k bits that all the k functions may hash this new word to. Question 4 asks the probability that all these k bits are set to 1, which is easy given the answer for question 3.

history.content:
The expectation is taken over the random choice of the bucket. To calculate this expected value you need to multiply the expected time for each bucket by
the probability of searching that bucket (which is 1/n) and then sum this product over all of the buckets.

children.subject: In the last part you are asked about the worst-case time, not the expected time. If you are asking about the second to last part. Note that a new item is one which is not in the table, this means that the algorithm will go through all of the elements in the bin until it concludes that the element is not there.

As for the third part, the elements that are not in the bucket 1, the time cost will be constant that can be ignored. As for the elements that in the bucket 1, the time could be 1/n*(1+2+3...+n/2). It seems that the result still contains n which makes the time cost is still O(n).

history.content:
You can think of each $$1\{h_i(A)=h_i(B)\}$$ as a bernouli random variable (ie 0/1 random variable) $$X_i$$ with probability/mean p. Then $$H = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^n{X_i}}{n}$$. 

You are right about $$E(H)$$, $$var(H) = E(H^2)-E(H)^2$$ , and $$E(H)^2 = p^2$$. However: $$E(H^2) \neq p^2$$. 

You can calculate $$var(H)$$ as follows:

$$var(H) = var(\frac{\sum_{i=1}^n{X_i}}{n}) = \frac{1}{n^2}var(\sum_{i=1}^n{X_i}) = \frac{1}{n^2}\sum_{i=1}^n{var(X_i)} = \frac{1}{n}var(X_i) = \frac{1}{n}p(1-p)$$

history.content:
I added a small clarification to the question on WebWork- your interpretation is correct, but not the question I meant to ask. Under your interpretation, I understand the number of processes drops dynamically as processes get access to the database. So if only k out of n had not accessed the database, only these processes would attempt access with probability 1/k. 

In that case, the probability a specific process $$P_i$$ out of the k processes gets access is $$\frac{1}{k}\(1-\frac{1}{k}\)^{k-1}$$, so the probability one of the k processes gets access is $$k*\frac{1}{k}(1-\frac{1}{k})^(k-1)$$

Note: you don't need to use union bound. For $$i \neq j$$ the events "$$P_i$$ gets access" and "$$P_j$$ gets access" are disjoint. So $$P(E_{t,1} \cup E_{t,2} \cup ... E_{t_k}) = \cup_i{E_{t,i}}$$

*But*, we're assuming that at every timestep, all of the $$n$$ processes continue to try accessing the database. Thus the probability of a specific process $$i$$ of the k processes getting access is $$\frac{1}{n}\(1-\frac{1}{n}\)^{n-1}$$, which you approximated in step 4. Call this approximation $$A_n \sim \frac{1}{n}\(1-\frac{1}{n}\)^{n-1}$$

Then the probability one of the $$k$$ processes gets access is $$kA_n$$,

history.content: The problem is asking you what's the probability where one of the k processes doesn't get access at time t+1, but does at time t+2.

children.subject:
Basically you have to multiply the probability that one of the k processes is accessed by the probability they aren't accessed.

It's like rolling a dice until you get a 6. The probability you get the 6 on your first roll is 1/6, and the probability you get it on the second roll is 5/6 x 1/6, since there's a 5/6 chance you fail one the first roll, and a 1/6 you succeed on the second. The probability you get it on the third is 5/6 x 5/6 x 1/6, and so on.

The same principle applies here.

history.content:
The goal is to compute the expected runtime of quicksort, which is $$\mathbb{E}(\sum_{i,j}{X_{i,j}})$$. We spend parts 1-6 trying to compute this. 

In part (1), we compute $$p_{i,j} = \mathbb{E}(X_{i,j})$$. Great, now if we could just sum this over all i,j, we'd be done. 

This is not so easy to compute. We do this by considering pairs of i,j that are separated by the same amount $$k-1$$. For a particular separation $$k-1$$, all of these pairs will have the same $$p_{ij}=2/k$$. 

We spend parts 2,3 calculating how many pairs i,j there are for each separation $$k-1$$. If we multiply this by $$p_{ij}$$ for some particular k, we get $$\mathbb{E}(l_k)$$. 

Finally, we can compute the expected runtime of quicksort as $$\sum_{k}{\mathbb{E}(l_k)}$$

The goal is to compute the expected runtime of quicksort, which is $$\mathbb{E}(\sum_{i,j}{X_{i,j}})$$.  We spend parts 1-6 trying to compute this.  

In part (1), we compute $$p_{i,j} = \mathbb{E}(X_{i,j})$$.  Great, now if we could just sum this over all i,j, we'd be done.  

This is not so easy to compute.  We do this by considering pairs of i,j that are separated by the same amount $$k-1$$.  For a particular separation $$k-1$$, all of these pairs will have the same $$p_{ij}=2/k$$.  

We spend parts 2,3 calculating how many pairs i,j there are for each separation $$k-1$$.  If we multiply this by $$p_{ij}$$ for some particular k, we get $$\mathbb(E){l_k}$$.  

Finally, we can compute the expected runtime of quicksort as $$\sum_{k}{\mathbb(E){l_k}}$$
