history.content: The answer is 1/(4n) (I'm not sure if I'm allowed to give the answer. If I'm not, please delete that), but I don't really know why.

*** Maximum variance question

variance: $$\frac{1}{n}p(1-p) = \frac{1}{n}(p - p^2)$$
derivative with respect to p: $$\frac{1}{n}(1 - 2p) = 0$$ &lt;=&gt; $$1-2p = 0$$ &lt;=&gt; $$p = 1/2$$

This is a local maxima (you can verify with second derivative if you wanted to), so $$\frac{1}{n}p(1-p) \leq \frac{1}{n}\frac{1}{2}\frac{1}{2} = \frac{1}{4n}$$

***Assume n is large enough that H is approximately normal

For each i, $$1\{h_i(A)=h_i(B)\}$$ is a random variable $$X_i$$ with mean p and variance p(1-p). Then $$H = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n{X_i}$$, an average of n independently, identically distributed random variables. 

The average of n iid random variables is approximately normal for large enough n.

*Maximum variance question*

variance: $$\frac{1}{n}p(1-p) = \frac{1}{n}(p - p^2)$$
derivative with respect to p: $$\frac{1}{n}(1 - 2p) = 0$$ &lt;=&gt; $$1-2p = 0$$ &lt;=&gt; $$p = 1/2$$

This is a local maxima (you can verify with second derivative if you wanted to), so $$\frac{1}{n}p(1-p) \leq \frac{1}{n}\frac{1}{2}\frac{1}{2} = \frac{1}{4n}$$

*Assume n is large enough that H is approximately normal*

For each i, $$1\{h_i(A)=h_i(B)\}$$ is a random variable $$X_i$$ with mean p and variance p(1-p).  Then $$H = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n{X_i}$$, an average of n independently, identically distributed random variables.  

The average of n iid random variables is approximately normal for large enough n.

history.content:
The question is randomized, let's say the question asked "what is an upper bound on P(H&lt;0.8) given p &gt; 0.9".  

We've assumed H is normal with mean p, so we are interested in the size of the normal's tail in the region $$(-\infty,0.8)$$.  The mean of this normal is at p &gt; 0.9, so in the worst-case (biggest tail), p = 0.9.

Then the problem just becomes: assume you have a normal centered at 0.9 with the upper-bound on variance you computed above, what is the size of the tail in $$(-\infty,0.8)$$?  Remember, this is a single tail.  So you just compute Q(normalized distance from 0.8 to 0.9).

history.content:
Phi is the cdf of a standard normal, Q is the right tail.
Phi(z) is the probability for the left side of z. Q(z) is the probability for the right side of z.

If the true score is $$p$$, then the sample mean $$\hat{p}$$ is a normal distribution centered at $$p$$. The threshold 0.8 can be used to find the z-score which is plugged into Phi or Q, depending on which area you want to compute.

No no, z-score should be (0.8-mu)/std. It depends on the true mean and number of samples. You dont look up a z-score from the chart, instead, the chart gives you the value of either Q(z) or Phi(z) for a certain z-score.

Each permutation is like a sample from a binary r.v. with probability $$p$$ of taking 1. This $$p$$ is the true similarity score. The estimated similarity score $$\hat{p}$$ obtained with $$k$$ minHash iterations is like the sample mean based on $$k$$ samples of this binary r.v. Now it should look like something we have done a lot in past assignments.

I'm having trouble understanding what exactly is going on. I know you're trying to explain it but I think I need it in simpler terms. So here is how I look at this problem: You're given 50 documents, you divide them into a minHash table with 25 permutations so would it look something like this: and if the output similarity score is less than 0.8 it is "dissimilar," if it is greater than 0.92 it is "similar" (if equal to .8 or .92 no judgement). the next part is where i get confused "For a certain document pair, define pˆ as the similarity score obtained from 25 iterations of minHash, and the true similarity score p." What is the difference between the similarity score and the true similarity score? next, "Recall that 25 iterations of minHash essentially draw 25 samples of a binary random variable with probability p of being 1" so p would be the probability that the outcome from the minHash is 1. so when solving the probability, Pr(pˆ≤0.8) it would take on the form "1 - Q(z-score)" now to get the z-score you would take .8-mu/std, here the mu would be the mean but isn't the sample mean pˆ? and then std is equal to sqrt(np(1-p)) where n will be 25 and p will be "p" and not an exact value? I'm trying to understand it but it's just not clicking with me and I get more confused when you describe it. Can you make it a bit more simpler please.

This question is simpler than you may think. The 50 documents are not supposed to be considered in a whole, just think about each individual pair. So say we are computing the similarity score of document A and B. The exact score is $$p = \frac{|A\cap B|}{|A\cup B|}$$, which requires counting all words in both documents and is expensive to compute. Here comes the minHash algorithm that estimates this score, $$\hat{p}$$, in a much faster way. Say we run the algorithm on A and B for $$k$$ iterations. In each iteration it hashes A to a random word in A, and hashes B to a random word in B, then compare the two words. If they match, count as 1, and otherwise 0. It turns out that in each iteration the probability of getting 1 is exactly $$p$$. So we run the algorithm for $$k$$ iterations, and use the sample mean of $$k$$ match/unmatch results to estimate this probability. Since this is a large sample estimate, we have the normal curve that describes its distribution, centered around the true mean of $$p$$. With this curve we can find the probability that $$\hat{p}$$ taking whatever value. This is just for one pair, which is what part 1-3 are about. Then we consider all the pairs among 50 documents, and all pairs have the same false negative rate. Note that the false negative rate of every pair is independent with another, so again, we have a large sample sum problem. I don't think visualizing the hash table will help you getting the concept here.

history.subject: hw21 problem 2 last part

history.content:
You are using the right formula,
Your mistake is using the optimal k from the problem before. Here you are asked to find m and the optimal k is a function
of m and n: $$k_{opt}=\left (\ln 2  \right ) \frac{m}{n}$$

So for 2 choices from 5 balls numbered 1 through 5. There are 5 "bins" which represent the numbers 1 through 5. We select 2 balls (with replacement) from the 5 balls. We have the following possible sets to represent the numbering of the balls when order does not matter

OK, I believe I finally understand your mistake... You write that the sample space is {1,1},{1,2}{1,3}{1,4}{1,5}{2,2}{2,3}{2,4}{2,5}{3,3}{3,4}{3,5}{4,4}{4,5}{5,5} and I assume that by that you mean that each of these 15 elements has the same probability of 1/15. But that is not correct, the uniform probability is over the set of unordered pairs, of which there are 25 (let's call this the "original" sample space. There are two types of pairs 1) pairs of the form {a,b} where a is not equal to b, correspond to two elements in this original space: {a,b} and {b,a}, therefor their probability is 2/25. 2) pairs of the form {a,a}, these corresponds to only one pair in the original space, thus they have probability 1/25. In total you have 10 pairs of probability 2/25 and 5 pairs of probability 1/25. Totalling 1 as they should. Now if you compute the probability that a=b you get 5*(1/25) = 5 When the number of draws is larger, say 15, then you get many different "types" of sequences, each with a different probability. It is hard work to keep count of all of them. Possible, but hard. It is much easier to consider ordered pairs. So, bottom line, when you switch from ordered to unordered in this problem you get a sample space with non-uniform probabilities, making it harder to calculate the probabilities of events. children.subject: Sure, normal distribution, central limit theorem, Z score, Q function, Qinv. Am I missing something?
Sometimes the z score = (X-u)/stdev but sometimes it's (X-u)/(stdev/n) when do we use which?

In all cases, the z-score for a value, say $$x$$, of a random variable $$X$$, is computed as $$(x-\mu_X)/\sigma_X$$. Notice the subscript of $$\mu_X$$ and $$\sigma_X$$, which means they are the mean and std of the random variable $$X$$.

Sometimes $$X$$ is the weight of a person, sometimes $$X$$ is the average weight of 100 person, sometimes $$X$$ is the sum of weight of 100 person. In each case, $$\mu_X$$ and $$\sigma_X$$ are different.

If in the first case, the mean is $$\mu_0$$ and the std is $$\sigma_0$$.
In the average-of-weight case, the mean is $$\mu_0$$ and the std is $$\sigma_0/\sqrt{n}$$.
In the sum-of-weight case, the mean is $$n*\mu_0$$ and the std is $$\sqrt{n}\sigma_0$$.
Can you go over the Q function stuffs on Friday lecture?
Maybe also skim through picking random questions from the webwork practice some more - if there is extra time.

$$\Phi$$ is the CDF (i.e. left tail) of a standard normal distribution. $$\Phi(z)$$ is the area under the curve from $$-\infty$$ to $$z$$.
$$Q$$ is the right tail of a standard normal distribution. $$Q(z)$$ is the area under the curve from $$z$$ to $$\infty$$.

history.subject: CB CP DP RA RV ST

history.content:
CB = combinatorics
DP = discrete probability
RV = random variables, mean variance
CP = conditional probability, Bayes rule
ST = statistics, normal distribution, z-value, Q/Phi functions, hypothesis testing
RA = randomized algorithms, hashing, minHash, bloom filter

This is the order of instruction, but you are free to try out in whatever order you like.

RA = randomized algorithms

Assume that women's weights are normally distributed with a mean given by μ=143 lb and a standard deviation given by σ=29 lb. 
(b)  If 4 women are randomly selected, find the probability that they have a mean weight between 123 lb and 166 lb

for part b/c wouldn't we just divide the standard deviation by the number of women and then use that to calculate the z-score of 166 and 123? 

This is my answer for part b, it keeps saying it's wrong though.

Phi[(166-143)/(29/4)]-Phi[(123-143)/(29/4)]
 I did the same thing with part C and got it right. Am I doing something wrong or is this an error? 
#testpreparationst
history.subject: TestPreparationST: Problem 3

history.content: The z-score is $$\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma_n}=\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma_1/\sqrt{n}}$$, where $$\sigma_1$$ is the std of the random variable.

history.content: I figured it out but I don't know when you use p(1-p) and,like in this case, when its 1/n *p * (1-p)

The variance of a single "Bernoulli random variable" is  $$p(1-p)$$. The Bernouli distribution is a distribution that takes on 1 with probability p, and 0 with probability (1-p). 
You can think of this random variable describing the flip of a single biased coin, 1=head, 0=tails, probability of heads is p. 

The variance for the distribution describing the average of the sum of n coins is $$\frac{1}{n}p(1-p)$$. 

The outcome $$1(h_i(A)=h_i(B))$$ is like the outcome of a coin flip. Either the min-hashes of the two sets are equal, or they are not. 

So you can think of the average of n of these as an average of n coin flips, each with probability p. Giving you the variance: $$\frac{1}{n}p(1-p)$$.

The variance for the distribution describing the average of the sum of n coins is $$\frac{1}{n}p(1-p)$$. 

The outcome of $$1(h_i(A)=h_i(B))$$ is just like the outcome of a coin flip. Either the min-hashes of the two sets are equal, or they are not. 

Thus you can think of the average of n of these as an average of n coin flips, each with probability p. Giving you the variance: $$\frac{1}{n}p(1-p)$$.

The variance of a single "Bernoulli random variable" is $$p(1-p)$$.  The Bernouli distribution is a distribution that takes on 1 with probability p, and 0 with probability (1-p).  
You can think of this random variable describing the flip of a single biased coin, 1=head, 0=tails, probability of heads is p.  

The variance for the distribution describing the average of the sum of n coins is $$\frac{1}{n}p(1-p)$$.  

The outcome of $$1(h_i(A)=h_i(B))$$ is just like the outcome of a coin flip.  Either the min-hashes of the two sets are equal, or they are not.  

Thus you can think of the average of n of these as an average of n coin flips, each with probability p.  Giving you the variance: $$\frac{1}{n}p(1-p)$$.

can someone explain how you arrive at the values for each one?

history.subject: TestPrep CP #6

history.content:
Assuming the value you got for percentage of students who spend time in the Math department resource room is 66%, the problem gives us that half of the students that spend time there spend 90 minutes or more time.so,

 Pr(1 to 90 minutes) = (1/2)*66% = .33 .

The other half(the half spends less than 90 min there) would also be .33 . The percentage who doesnt spend time there would be

 Pr(0 min) = 1-Pr(kids go to room) = (1-66%) = .34.

Also remember that Pr(nopass|0 minutes) means the probability that the student didnt pass given that he spent 0 minutes in the math department room. The problem gives us that 29 percent of the students who do not go to the room pass, 
 
 so Pr(nopass|0 min) = 1-Pr(pass| 0 min)= 1 - .29 = .71

likewise, you can get the values for Pr(nopass|1 to 90 min) and Pr(nopass|over 90 min).

However, it seems as if the Pr(0 minutes), Pr(1 to 90 minutes) and Pr(over 90 minutes) values in the second part of your hints are inconsistent with the values in the first part. This issue occurred on my problem too, so I am assuming its a typo. You should use the same values as given in the first part of the hint.

So Pr(nopass|0 minutes)Pr(0 minutes) should equal .71*.34
 Pr(nopass|1 to 90 minutes)Pr(1 to 90 minutes) should equal .58*.33
 Pr(nopass|over 90 minutes)Pr(over 90 minutes) should equal .31*.33

So i think that the problem may have a typo itself....  can a TA or instructor check this problem please?

history.content:
Anyone can tell me how to decide whether a coin a fair or not? 
#15
history.subject: homework15 #2 last part

history.content:
Suppose you see a sequence with 10 heads and 90 tails. You calculate the probability that a fair coin would generate 
a sequence with 90 or more tails. If this probability is very small then you decide that the coin is not fair.
What is the maximal probability that is considered "very small" ? Typically a number between 1% and 5%.

A better wording of the question would be "Can you infer that the coin is not fair with significance 1%?"

children.subject: Just to check the probability of the occurrence of 10 heads and 90 tails.  Though in this case, we can assume that the coin is not fair already because we already know the probability of getting 90 tails is very small.  But if it was a number that was, say 63 tails, then we would have to calculate the probability because it is less apparent if the likelihood is small.

I see. So basically if I get the probability and find that it is between 1%-5% then I can decide that it is not unbiased.
Is it correct?

well then you would compare it to the significance value.  If they are asking for a significance level of 1%, and you calculate that there is 3 percent chance of it happening, then you would consider the coin unbiased.  But if it was a significance level of 5%, then the coin would be biased.
Sorry, I am kinda confused. Is p the significance value or alpha?

why you need to calculate the the probability that a fair coin would generate 
a sequence with 90 or more tails? If it is fair, the number of the heads should be near 50, right?

history.content:
I am not sure why you are adding up the two z-scores.  First of all z-scores should never be added then evaluated, because the Q-function wouls not yield the same answer for Q(1) + Q(2) and Q(1+2).  Look at a graph of standard distribution and you should understand this.

Also, the Q function is always the area on the right side of the z-score, or in this problem, it is the probability of the weight being above the given value.  So Q((-20/(29/sqrt(6))) and Q((21/(29/sqrt(6))) are essentially the probability of the weight over 123 and the probability of weight over 164, respectively.  However, the values overlap, therefore you need to subtract the smaller probability from the bigger value to get the probability of weight being between 123 and 164.

So I don't understand why can you use stars and bars for this question. If you use stars and bars, there will be configurations like "||*********" where all the values tries to go to the last dice. However, a six sided dice cannot possibly have a value of 7+. Can someone explain how does this stars and bars work? or am I just imagining it the wrong way

history.content: Sorry. We did not realize that this problem randomly picks questions to present you with. We have fixed it. Please try again.

Type II error (false negative) is: A. Deciding alternative hypothesis is true when it is true B. Deciding alternative hypothesis is false when it is true C. Deciding null hypothesis is false when it is true D. Not rejecting null hypothesis when it is false What's the difference between B. and D. ? If null hypothesis is "nothing is new" and alternative hypothesis is "medicine is new", then not rejecting null hypothesis is the same as embracing null hypothesis, which would be rejecting alternative hypothesis (declaring it false). Also, when null hypothesis is false, then the alternative hypothesis would be true. #testpreparation
history.subject: what's the difference?

history.content: One is a false positive, one is a false negative - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type_I_and_type_II_errors

children.subject:
"Not rejecting null hypothesis when it is false" can be reworded as:
Deciding null hypothesis is true when it is false,
which is the same as:
Deciding alternative hypothesis is false when it is true...
In other words, deciding null hypothesis is true == deciding alternative hypothesis is false
and also, null hypothesis is false == alternative hypothesis is true
so both B. and D. appear to be a Type II error

a false positive (Type I error) would be:
Deciding alternative hypothesis is TRUE when it is FALSE

history.content: The caveat here is: "not reject" is NOT the same as "accept". Deciding alternative hypothesis is false would be deciding null hypothesis is true, which hypothesis testings never do.

history.content:
Why you need to take powers of C(24,x)? 
$$\textbf{Pr}(x \text{ among } n \text{ people are independent}) = C(n,x)p^x(1-p)^{n-x}$$

Why you need to take powers of C(24,x)? 
$$Pr(x\text{ among }n\text{ people are independent})=C(n,x)p^x(1−p)^(n−x)$$

Why you need to take powers of C(24,x)? 
$$Pr(x among n people are independent)=C(n,x)p^x(1−p)^(n−x)$$

I got the right answer but my reasoning is different from the hint given. 

My answer is: (5!/(3!(2!)))*((1/36)^2)*((35/36)^3)

We were told to find the missing probability which is the probability of getting 12s exactly two times out of 5 rolls. Well I knew that there is a 1/36 chance to roll a 12 and 35/36 chance to get any other sum. Since we are looking for 2 rolls to be 12, two rolls out of 5 will each have a probability of 1/36 of getting a 12, and 3 out of 5 rolls will each have a 35/36 probability to get a sum other than 12. However we need to also take into account how many different ways 2 out of 5 12s can be rolled. So we must do C(5,2) in order to figure out how many ways we can pick 2 of those rolls to be 12s out of 5 rolls. Now we just multiply everything together C(5,2)*(1/36)^2*(35/36)^3 and that's the answer.

children.subject:
• Using Chebyshev’s inequality, what is an upper bound on the probability your “majority algorithm” is incorrect?
  • What is the smallest real number t such that if n≥t the probability that the “majority algorithm” makes an error is at most 0.05?
For the first part I got: 3/16/n/0.25^2 = 3/n For the second part I got: 3/0.05, from 3/n = 0.05 => n = 3/0.05

To get 20, the original formula that we figured out in part 1 was (1/n*(3-1)/3*(1-(3-1)/3))/((3-1)/3-1/2)^2
So we substitute n with .05 in the second part, and 1/0.05 is 20 :)

history.content:
All final exam papers are graded. You can see the results on the updated scoresheet (https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/ccc?key=0Ag7fHWCRBqu8dHgzOXFsTmRhRE5Ob3hDZUU0cW9rQ1E#gid=0).

The final score is composed of 45% assignment average, 10% attendance score, 45% final.

The assignment average is computed by normalizing each of the 21 assignments, and then take the average.
The attendance score is 10 if you missed no more than 2 classes, and then reduced in proportion to the number of extra absences.
The final score is out of 90, except for the three students who took the early exam (the scores for these students shown on the scoresheet are scaled to 90).

A+ is assigned to students with course average over 99, then A to those over 95, A- to those over 90, etc....

Let me know at yuncong@ucsd.edu if you find any problem in the scoresheet.

Thank you all for participating in this course. Hope you will find the materials useful in future study.

Enjoy the holiday!
- Yuncong Chen

children.subject: I was not aware of such a norm. Is it posted somewhere?
I was just wondering why there is such a large cut off for - marks aka an 95 is an A and a 94 would be an A- I thought a 93 was the norm for such a cutoff?

history.content:
The final grades are now posted (we found the 4 missing final exams).

If you want to check your final exam, you can go to CSE students services center. Ask to see the final exams for CSE103, Fall 2012.
You can read your final exam, but you cannot take it with you. When you are done reviewing it, leave it in it's right place in the box.

If you want to contest the grade you got on the exam, you need to contact your reviewer:
Version 1: Yoav Freund, yfreund@ucsd.edu
Version 2: Matt Elkherj: melkherj@ucsd.edu
Version 3: Yuncong Chen: yuncong@ucsd.edu

Yoav
